On Saturday morning I will also be attending a commemoration of the avenue of flags in Cooma, where all of the flags of the participating nations will be flown—and I really look forward to that. I congratulate everybody who has been involved in these celebrations. Many other things have been happening throughout the year. The Snowy scheme people have done an excellent job. In particular, I want to acknowledge Vin Good, who was the acting commissioner over the last few years until recently and is still there as the associate commissioner. He has been the driving force behind these celebrations, and I look forward to a great weekend with Vin and everybody else. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This evening I want to talk about a university. I want to talk about the university I attended and graduated from. It is a regional university—Newcastle University—and it plays a very important role in the whole of the Hunter community. The reason it plays an important role is that it holds out hope to all of those people who want to break free of the traditional work patterns in the coalmines and in the steel industry and who know that the only way they will do that is by getting a university education. That is probably more so today than at any time in history—when knowledge and information are vitally important. I am old enough to remember the Whitlam era that made university education available to all.
—You don't look it.

—No, I know that, but at the time Whitlam came to power I had been teaching for about 12 years and I can distinctly remember the heartache of counselling parents who had to make the decision: `How can we send our children to university? If we have a bright daughter and a son that is probably not as good a student, which one do we send?' After all, in those days the girls were going to get married and they did not have a career. That was the sort of heartache that families went through in that era. As a result of this leaked document, that is the sort of thing I can see coming back into Australian society.
—Rubbish.

—It may be rubbish to people on that side, but I am sure you have never confronted the problems of the people in the Hunter—an area that, despite its enormous wealth and its great diversity and productivity, is suffering from unemployment at twice the rate of the national average.
—He doesn't exactly know where it is.

—No, that is exactly right. This is a government that sat on its hands and allowed the steel industry to close. This is a government that has a minister that takes great delight in telling Australia, `I am proud that we have done away with the referee and that there have been 2,000 coalminers out of work in the last two years.' These are the sorts of problems that are confronting the Hunter—and now they have another problem on top of that. They have a promise by a minister in the Howard government that university education is not going to be universally available; it is going to be available to those who can afford to pay. There are many people in the Hunter who will not be able to pay. I can guarantee that. You cannot afford to send your child to university when you do not have a job, when you are worried about losing your home, when you are trying to eke out an existence on the dole. It does not matter how bright your child is, you cannot afford to send him or her to university. That is the tragedy that has befallen Australia with the exposure of this document today.

speech.para: I look forward to seeing the papers tomorrow, just to see how the people of Australia when they wake up and read about this react to what this government—with family values—believes is good for the young people of Australia. When I look around the House, I realise there are more graduates of Newcastle University than just me. It is really a great university. But it is not only happening at the University at Newcastle, the pattern is repeated all over the country—

talk.start.para: —Armidale.

—Armidale, the University of New England, the University of Western Sydney. These are the places that shine like beacons to all of those families. They know that the pace of change of Australian society is enormous. Yet Australian families are prepared to give, and give generously, as long as their kids have a chance. As of today, I believe they are on notice that that chance is going to be denied them. That will be a tragedy. It is something that is going to divide Australia into classes. Those who can afford it will be able to go to the sandstone universities, as the shadow minister said today, and the others will be condemned to whatever life holds for them, without an education. They may have the ability, but this government will deny them the opportunity to live out their opportunities to the best of their ability.

—Like many members of the House, I have received a number of letters regarding the Jubilee 2000 program and requests from constituents that the government do more to help those poor countries that are heavily in debt. For this reason, I was delighted when, the week before last, the Treasurer announced at the World Bank meeting Australia's commitment to increasing its allocation of funds to help those heavily indebted poor countries. That is an increase of $35 million, bringing Australia's total commitment up to $65 million.

speech.para: This is part of a package whereby the wealthier countries are now committing $27 billion in total. Add that to a number of other programs of $20 billion worth of debt relief and IMF and World Bank relief and that brings a total package of about $100 billion to reduce the debt profile of those heavily indebted poor countries. The problem that these countries face cannot be underestimated and a couple of figures may illustrate this. The foreign debt of the 41 poorest countries in the world has, over the last 20 years, grown from $60 billion to $200 billion. Thirty-five of the poorest countries in the world have a foreign debt over 100 per cent of their GDP. Eighteen of the poorest countries in the world have debt servicing to export ratios of over 30 per cent. Many of them are borrowing just to pay the accumulated interest and to service their debt and are not making any impact at all on the capital amount outstanding.

The point is that these heavily indebted countries do not just face a static debt problem; they face a self-perpetuating debt problem, that the further they go on the further into debt they get. The fact that they have high debt to begin with means that they face high interest payments, high debt servicing costs. Those high debt servicing costs then feed further into their current account deficit exacerbating their foreign debt problems. So it is not a one-off problem that can be addressed. It is a self-perpetuating cycle of debt: higher payments, higher current account deficit and further debt.

There are many other angles on this self-perpetuation of their problems. The fact that they have high and increasing current account deficits means they face currency depreciations. The currency depreciation then further aggravates the problem. The currency depreciation means that the valuation in foreign dollars of their debt rises, their ability to pay that debt in domestic currency diminishes further and they face ever increasing interest payments because of their growing current account and debt problems. So they are locked into a self-perpetuating cycle, out of which it is almost impossible for many of them to escape. This is just one of the cycles of despair, if you like, that these countries face.

The fact that they have high debt and high servicing costs and a weak currency makes it hard for them to attract foreign investment because of the instability and the weakness of their currency. If they cannot attract foreign investment, they cannot get the capital they need and their productivity remains low. If their productivity is low, it is hard for them to generate the extra income that they need in order to grow and in order to service the debt. It is typical of the sorts of problems these countries have. They have low levels of GDP and income. There is no surplus income; therefore their levels of domestic savings are low. If their levels of domestic savings are low, they cannot finance capital investment. If they have low levels of capital investment, productivity levels stay low. If productivity is low, the low income cycle starts all over again.

The cycle of debt that these heavily indebted poor countries find themselves in is one from which it is almost impossible to escape. For this reason, I am delighted that Australia has increased its commitment and that many countries in the world have made a large commitment to help reduce the debt problem that these countries face. Australia, in conjunction with other governments, with NGOs and with the United Nations, is doing a lot to help these problems already, particularly in the poorest areas of Papua New Guinea, South Africa, South-East Asia, South Asia and Africa. Together, we are providing emergency relief programs, food aid, health and clean water supplies, education, rural development and infrastructure. I would like to see us doing more, but we are increasing our commitment to these countries and I am delighted that that is happening.

Another point that needs to be made is that aid is not a substitute for having sound social and economic policies. These countries need to develop sound social and economic policies themselves. Aid is also not a substitute for removing corruption and inefficient government. It is not a substitute for responsible government on the part of these countries. Further, there is a capacity, through the tax deductibility that our government gives to private donations, for individuals to contribute to aid through many NGOs and through aid work overseas. The Australian government subsidises through tax deductibility the donations that Australian citizens give to many valuable overseas aid programs. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have said many times that I come from a most beautiful place in Australia but, unfortunately, we also have serious economic and social problems. We have one of the highest unemployment rates in Australia, and more than half of the population is receiving Commonwealth benefits of some kind or another. Also, unfortunately, we have some of the lowest retention rates for years 11 and 12 and for higher education in Australia.

speech.para: It was therefore with some trepidation that, given these circumstances, I heard today the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, in his demand driven systems option, talk about a universal tuition subsidy which follows a student to accredited higher education courses; student fees for tuition being set by the providers, which was his preferred model; a universal loan scheme to help students pay tuition costs with a real rate of interest repayable through the tax system on an income contingent basis; institutions rather than the government setting the price for a course of study; the current HECS system being abolished; and the income contingent government loans, again with real rate of interest repayable through the tax system, being available to finance the cost of tuition of any accredited higher education institution. That makes me wonder: if it is bad enough now in my electorate, I cannot see how it could get better. It could only get worse.

For instance, since 1996, the Commonwealth higher education budget has cut operating grants to the University of Tasmania and reduced the number of Commonwealth funded places. Indeed, at the end of this year, the university would have reduced its operating budget in the order of $10 million and have shed 408 student places. But expansion, not contraction, is needed in the university to confer economic benefits on the state. How are we going to have expansion in university places rather than contraction when we introduce universal tuition subsidies, when we deregulate the system and when we introduce vouchers and, again, this universal loan scheme with real interest rates?

I mentioned before that the retention rates in my state are some of the lowest in Australia. Indeed, on the north-west coast, for instance, the higher education participation rate is 55 per cent below the national average. So we would expect a government to target its initiatives to areas of need. But what do we have? There was a precursor to what we heard today in this demand driven system and the option that the minister prefers. The precursor was the abolition of the merit based scholarship scheme. People in my electorate directly benefited from it. In fact, 11 of the 21 offered in 1999 went to north-west coast students. Since 1996, 30 of the 68 scholarships offered by the University of Tasmania went to west-north-west students. But what happened to that? It was abolished, and we were told that that was in consultation with university campus counsellors. But in actual fact, when we reviewed that, none of them had had any consultation on this at all. No, this was a precursor of what was to come.

The minister's document, which the members over there have not received yet—and it will make interesting reading, particularly in the regional and rural areas, let me assure you—talked about one of the benefits. It states:

The requirement to preserve a specified proportion of premium fee income for equity initiatives should be a political plus. Such initiatives funded by institutions rather than the government might include part or full scholarships to cover fees.

If you do not have enough dough in your economy already, how are you going to get people to give benefits and donations to a scholarship scheme for people who will not go to university anyway because it is too expensive now and it is going to be too expensive later? Regions like my own will be left to drift, as they have in the past. The University of Tasmania, try the best it can for the campus of the Burnie district, will be left to wonder what has happened.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise the subject of suicide and youth suicide this evening. In my maiden speech in 1996, I mentioned the issue of youth suicide and the tragedy involved, particularly on the Central Coast of New South Wales. It was an issue that was affecting us greatly in our area.

speech.para: It was also an issue that came to the notice of our local coroner, Bryan Wilson, and he realised that official figures and statistics were not being kept throughout New South Wales and Australia. We on the Central Coast organised the first community initiated summit to look at how things could be organised in a way that could help reduce the impact of youth suicide. I am pleased to say that, some three years down the track, we believe that, through the Central Coast Suicide Safety Network, we have been able to make a significant impact on the number of youth suicides on the Central Coast of New South Wales.

The youth suicide rate on the Central Coast has been dropping annually, and we believe that that is at least in part due to the injection of state and federal government funds of some $3 million allowing for the set up of that Suicide Safety Network. In fact, when I say only five young people suicided on the Central Coast, which is some two-thirds reduction on the numbers, it is still five too many, but it is a very significant drop compared with the figures of last year. So I believe that the suicide safety model is one that should be looked at throughout the rest of Australia.

There is another problem with suicide that really does not receive a great deal of attention—that is, the suicide rate of males aged between 25 and 44. That seems to be ever increasing. It is a tragedy not only for the families involved but for Australia because it is a time when men seem to be involved in their workplace and with raising their families and dealing with the pressures of families. Often it is as a result of disputes that end up in the Family Court or custody battles. It is taking an immense toll that seems to be reflecting particularly in male suicide.

Great work has been done by Chaplain Eric Trezise, who has been at the forefront of the Suicide Safety Network. Eric has been working hard to raise the profile of this issue because he realises that it is not getting the public profile that the youth suicide has been getting over the years. In fact, Eric Trezise is addressing the National Coroners Conference tomorrow in Canberra and will be delivering a speech on this subject. He has prepared a submission, which he will be forwarding to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Michael Wooldridge. We have spoken with Michael Wooldridge on this subject.

But, importantly, we would like to see further community consultation. That is one of the initiatives that Eric is proposing, and hopefully a national congress on adult male suicide may be able to be held in the year 2000. To be able to do something like that takes the involvement of the state governments. It is very important that the state governments become involved.

talk.start.para: —took the chair at 9.48 a.m.

—I would like to draw the attention of the House to the plight of Mr Nasrullah Wahidi, an Afghani who was denied a protection visa in a decision by the Refugee Review Tribunal, No. V99/10339, on 28 September this year. Mr Wahidi worked as a dentist in Afghanistan. He had a female patient who consulted him on three occasions. On the first two occasions she was accompanied by a child. On the third visit the applicant had to uncover her face—that is, lift her veil—to fit a denture he had made for her. The applicant left the room to make some adjustments to the denture, and when he returned the Taliban were there. The applicant was accused of being an adulterer. He was told that the woman had been followed and that they were aware this was the third time she had come to see him. He later learnt that the Taliban had a checkpoint outside his surgery.

speech.para: The applicant is not in any way linked to any particular political group. He has rightly claimed that the Taliban are against socially well-known families that are well educated and that the Taliban wished to discredit them amongst the community. For this reason, they created a false impression against the applicant. The Taliban are of the view that scholars are only those people who study religion, and they do not recognise other professions or fields of study.

The applicant explained that he had a female patient who wanted a front denture. On the first visit, she came to be measured; on the second visit, he fixed the denture with wax; and on the third visit, he was to ensure that it fitted properly. The applicant's clinic had four sections, and on the third visit he had gone to another section to fit the denture. He returned from that section to the theatre only to be beaten with a gun by the Taliban who were in the surgery. The applicant was taken to an office at the police station and kept there for 16 days. He was beaten and tortured, and they tried to force him to make a statement that he had raped the woman. They said that she visited him on three occasions and they were suspicious.

The applicant was asked whether the allegation was one of rape or adultery. He responded that the allegation was a sort of adultery and because of the relationship the consequence was rape. The applicant believes that he was accused of this crime because of the general intention to discredit educated people. When the applicant was in detention he was taken to the mosque five times a day to pray. Due to his habit of smoking cigarettes, he befriended a guard who asked him about his crime and he swore that he was innocent. The guard informed him that, when the Mullah returned from the front line, he would be stoned. The guard agreed to help him escape.

The upshot of this is that the applicant has asked the tribunal to consider his application on humanitarian grounds. Although the applicant is at risk of harm if he returns to Afghanistan, the tribunal is limited to determining whether the applicant satisfies the criteria for the grant of a protection visa. Consideration of this rests with the minister. I urge the minister to grant a protection visa. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to inform the House of the success of a major Aboriginal sporting event in my electorate recently. This year's New South Wales Aboriginal Rugby League Association knockout was held over the October long weekend in Dubbo. The three-day carnival attracted 64 football teams from throughout the state, the largest entry figure for 29 years of the competition. With the players came at least 20,000 family members, friends and supporters, according to organisers and police.

speech.para: The on-field action was spectacular, but the additional preparations and features of this huge undertaking also deserve mention. One of the most positive innovations was mandatory comprehensive health checks for the players. This served to gauge the players' fitness to take the field and also acted as a one-stop scan for other prevalent illnesses such as diabetes. Furthermore, sample bags for children contained educational material, while information was also readily available on a range of health and housing issues pertinent to Aboriginal communities.

Anxiety about the influx of 20,000 visitors along with the thousands of other long weekend tourists was allayed by the inclusion of several indigenous police and security officers, along with other measures. For example, the alcohol-free venue provided a relaxed family atmosphere for the visitors and non-indigenous Dubbo people alike and played host to between 15,000 and 20,000 spectators on Saturday alone.

Senior Dubbo police were so impressed by the organisation of the event and the behaviour of those attending that they made special mention of both in the Dubbo media in the days following. Organisers staged evening celebrations in the RAAF hangar leased especially for the occasion, which also eased the pressure on city nightspots. A number of hoteliers also expressed their appreciation for the manner in which the numbers had been handled.

A ban on sales of bottled alcohol throughout the city over the weekend was praised by hoteliers. But organisers also credit regulations to maintain order, which include the penalty for unruly fans being possible expulsion of their particular team from the event. Apparently the success of the rule in almost completely eliminating antisocial behaviour over the weekend also lay in the desire of teams not to forfeit their registration fee by not getting a shot at the considerable prize money.

The event was a tremendous success, bringing an estimated $6 million in income to Dubbo's economy due to the skill and professionalism of the organising committee and the commitment of fans to a blemish-free weekend. The bulk of the organisational workload was taken on by sisters from one of Dubbo's most renowned sporting families, the Peachys. Irene, Eunice and Cathy Peachy won personal praise from zone police inspector Ron Bender and Dubbo City Council officials for their efforts. With a blend of security and sensitivity they stage-managed the biggest sporting carnival in Dubbo for a decade, hosted thousands of visitors and showcased the city in the best possible light. They helped inject millions of dollars into the local economy but, more importantly, provided Aboriginal people with an opportunity to shrug off stereotypes and confound any detractors. To the credit of the people who came from near and far to do just that in my electorate, I congratulate you.

talk.start.para: —One of the most rewarding things about my work as a parliamentarian is the opportunity it provides for meeting and working with the younger members of my community. I am constantly amazed and delighted by the achievements of our youth. They live in a society that is far less secure than the one in which I grew up. I did not have to worry about whether I would get a job—just which one. I grew up secure in the knowledge that my family was likely to stay together, my dad would have a job until retirement and everyone in the street knew each other. I had an extended family that maintained the old traditions and rituals that made me feel safe.

speech.para: My friends and I enjoyed a life relatively free of violence, real or virtual. Of course we had our fears. Our parents experienced war on a worldwide magnitude, we knew what the atomic bomb was capable of and later we lived through the tragedies of Korea and Vietnam. But all that seemed remote; all was so safe at home. Violent crime, drug abuse and poverty existed, of course, but to a far lesser extent than that to which our youth are exposed today.

Our young people care. They care about their future, their families and their community, both local and global. They have a strong sense of loyalty and abhor injustice and corruption, especially when it is linked with the very people and organisations we have taught them to respect. We have a strange tendency to sell our young people short. Our media focuses on the handful of unfortunate, misguided individuals who display antisocial or criminal behaviour. These are very much in the minority. I am tired of hearing and reading sensationalist, negative commentary about our young people when the vast majority are hardworking, resourceful, creative and honest.

We would do well to remind ourselves of the lessons we have taught and the standards we have set. We ought to look at the state of the environment that we are handing to our youth. We should take a good, hard look at the effect of the media, the entertainment industry and the type of material that is so accessible throughout the Internet. Our young people did not create this stuff; our generation did. Is it any wonder that some of our youth are confused? They are being exploited and criticised at the same time. What are we teaching our kids; what example are we setting?

I am fortunate to have the pleasure of meeting hundreds of young people each year as I travel in my electorate. I never cease to be impressed by their dedicated efforts to improve their world. They are working for the health of our natural environment, for their schools, for their sporting clubs and for their families and friends. Let us acknowledge the outstanding efforts of our youth, look at ways in which we can improve the example we are setting them and, at the same time, do everything in our power to support them, listen to them and acknowledge their efforts.

talk.start.para: —I recollect that the Minister for Sport and Tourism mentioned yesterday that we could expect four million overseas visitors to Australia this year for the fourth year in a row. I want to reflect on the customer service experience that those four million visitors might receive when they come to this country. Probably it is true to say that the taxi drivers and waiters of Sydney have a bigger impact on Australia's relationship with other nations than the entire diplomatic corp combined.

speech.para: The reality is that those four million visitors will largely form their view of Australia on the basis of their customer service experience. There have been many leaders in the field of trying to lift the standard of customer service in Australia—for example, my parliamentary colleague the member for Cook who, as head of the Tourism Council of Australia, was a passionate advocate of customer service. There is no doubt that great strides forward have been made in the tourism and hospitality sector.

talk.start.para: —Aussie host.
—The Aussie host program is another example. It has run a series of seminars and training programs accrediting the hospitality sector in customer focus.

speech.para: I want to turn today to one young Australian who has a passion for customer service. His name is Brett Whitford. He is the Executive Director of the Customer Service Institute of Australia. He is working with a single-minded focus and determination to lift levels of excellence in customer service around the country. Brett benefits from the legendry corporate leader and motivator Brad Cooper, who has chairmanship of the institute. They are putting the spotlight on this issue for all of us.

One of the endearing qualities of the Australian character is an egalitarian spirit that says that Jack is as good as his master. We benefit from avoiding the strictures of a rigid class system which has bedevilled some of our European counterparts. The downside, or the risk, of this charming egalitarian spirit is that we never fully appreciate the joy of service. We sometimes confuse professional service with civility or subservience. The Customer Service Institute is working through the development of standards and accreditation and running quality audits to lift the consciousness of customer service.

Most members would agree that when you have an outstanding customer service experience you never forget it. The Jews had wisdom when they said, `Remember the widow, the orphan and the sojourner in your midst'—the traveller among you. I especially want to acknowledge the efforts of Ramzi Chahine, who is the concierge at the Parkroyal, Parramatta. Ramzi Chahine is a legend in customer service. He exceeds my expectations every day I park my car in that building. I hope other Australian service providers will follow his example. (Time expired)
